column1: A ureterocele is a swelling at the bottom of one of the tubes (ureters) that carry urine from the kidney to the bladder.
A ureterocele can also cause urine to flow backward from the bladder to the kidney.
Ureteroceles occur in about 1 in 500 to 1 in 4,000 people.

Symptoms include: - Abdominal pain - Back pain that may be only on one side - Severe side (flank) pain and spasms that may reach to the groin, genitals, and thigh - Blood in the urine - Burning pain while urinating (dysuria) - Fever - Foul-smelling urine - Frequent and urgent urination - Lump (mass) in the abdomen that can be felt - Ureterocele tissue falls down (prolapse) through the female urethra and into the vagina - Urinary incontinence - Urinary tract infection
Antibiotics are often given to prevent further infections until surgery can be done.
Drains placed in the ureter or renal area (stents) may provide short-term relief of symptoms.

Complications may include: - Long term bladder damage (incontinence/urinary retention) - Long term kidney damage, including loss of function in one kidney - Urinary tract infection that keeps coming back
